title: Blind dad unable to buy Christmas gift for son as poverty 'destroys his life'
text:

A blind dad has bravely told how his descent into poverty left him with so little that he couldn't afford a Christmas gift for his son.

Derek Kelter, 55, said poverty destroyed "everything" in his life and he hit a "new low" last Christmas when he had no money for presents.

Mr Kelter, from Motherwell, North Lanarkshire, suffered a brain injury just before his 50th birthday which left him struggling and unable to find work.

He told the Daily Record he was later made redundant and his marriage broke down, and he hasn't been able to find a job that can accommodate his disability.

Mr Kelter had worked as a campaigner for disability rights after being left blind and paralysed following a respiratory arrest at age 15.

(Image: Daily Record)

Since his second brain injury he has been forced into poverty.

He has signed up as a community activist for The Poverty Alliance and has bravely shared his story to call for a solution.

It comes on the heels of Mirror Online's Town 2020 series which investigated the problems plaguing Britain's towns - from poverty to crime - and what needs to be done to solve them.

Mr Kelter said: “Poverty destroys everything in your life. A low for me was last Christmas, when I had no money to buy my son a Christmas present.

“The ­situation we have today is ­unacceptable. We need to get together to solve it.”

(Image: UGC)

He is taking part in events marking Challenge Poverty Week to highlight the barriers faced by those living in poverty.

He added: “We should all be able to live a dignified life but too many people are trapped in poverty. I’m blind and I’ve been locked out of employment since I had a brain injury five years ago.

"It doesn’t have to be this way though. Social security benefits should be enough so that people can live a dignified life and ­disabled people should be given support to access employment.

Peter Kelly, director of The Poverty Alliance, said: “All across ­Scotland people are coming together to highlight the problem of poverty and show what we can do to overcome the barriers that lock so many people in it.”

A new report has warned that Scotland's fight against poverty is in danger of “unravelling” unless action is taken across government.

The Joseph Rowntree Foundation raised concern in a report on poverty over the 20 years of Scottish devolution.

Poverty rates are almost four percentage points lower than when the Scottish Parliament opened. But the foundation say it’s not enough.

Jim McCormick, associate director of the foundation in Scotland, said: “Over the last two decades, cheaper rents and a larger social rented sector in Scotland have been key to unlocking opportunities for families to achieve a decent life.

"But this success is showing signs of unravelling and cannot be taken for granted.”

He said SNP ministers have to match ambitious targets with greater focus on housing and devolved social security.
